content: The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" is the short title for this Act, which includes a permanent extension of modifications to the Earned Income Tax Credit. The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, such as increasing the credit percentage for families with 3 or more children and raising the limit for joint returns from $3,000 to $5,000. The table in subparagraph (A) is adjusted by replacing '40' with '45'. Joint returns now have a limit of $5,000 instead of $3,000. Inflation adjustments for calendar year 2008 are also made. A conforming amendment removes paragraph (3) from the Code. These amendments are effective immediately. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to lower the eligibility age for youth formerly in foster care to 18. Additionally, a new section is added for returns relating to youth in foster care. "SEC. 6050X. Returns relating to youth in foster care, lowering eligibility age to 18." SEC. 6050X requires State, local, or tribal agencies to report data to the Adoption and Foster Care Analysis and Reporting System for individuals in foster care aged 16 and above. Agencies only need to report once for each individual unless specified by the Secretary. The return must be made in the form and manner prescribed by the Secretary. State, local, or tribal agencies are not required to make a return for an individual in foster care aged 16 and above for any subsequent calendar year. The return must include the individual's name, date of birth, TIN, identification number for the child welfare system, and other information as prescribed by the Secretary.
